726471f-d.text:
(1)
Ditmars Boulevard, north side, east of Shore Boulevard, showing an A.D. Ditmars house from 1873 to 1891. John A. Barto also resided here, so did one Mothman, a silk weaver. Judge Shipman was another resident. The house was demolished in November 1933.
1922.
E. L. Ambruster Collection.
(2)
The same.
March 1923.
Eugene L. Ambruster Collection.
(3)
The same.
April 1925.
Eugene L. Ambruster Collection.
(4)
The same, viewed northwestward showing at the left the East River (Hell Gate) and the Hell Gate Bridge (New York Connecting Railroad Bridge). At the right partially shown is the Nesbitt (also known as
Nesmith) House.
April 1925.
Eugene L. Ambruster Collection.

(1)
Ditmars Boulevard, north side, east of Shore Boulevard (left), showing the A. O. Ditmars house. Beyond it (white house) is the

726472f-a.folder: Ditmars Boulevard & Shore Boulevard, Queens, NY

727987f-b.text:
Shore Boulevard (foreground), east side, north of Ditmars Boulevard, showing the A. D. Ditmars house. In 1653 this land was granted to Philip Gerarety. Captain William Penfold purchased it in 1719; his son, who died in 1764, was the next owner. Dr. Dow Ditmars purchased it in 1816. He was followed by Abraham D. Ditmars who was also mayor of Long lIsland City from 1873 to 1875. The house remained in the ownership of the Ditmars family until 1891. This is a set of four views. In view No. 4 is also seen a part of the Hell Gate Bridge; in No. 2 is also seen the Nesbitt
house.
1923.
Views 2 & 3: March 1923.
View 4: April 1925.
Eumene L. Armbruster Collection.
727987f-b.folder: Shore Boulevard & Ditmars Boulevard, Queens, NY

727988f-c.text:
Shore Boulevard (left), north from Ditmars Boulevard, showing in a set of three views the A. D. Ditmars house. This house was demolished
prior to 1928. See other views for more data.
April 1925.
Views 2 3 3: 1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
